'''''Grifola frondosa''''' is a [[polypore]] [[mushroom]] that grows in clusters at the base of trees, particularly [[oak]]s.  The mushroom is commonly known among English speakers as '''hen of the woods''', '''hen-of-the-woods''', '''ram's head''' and '''sheep's head'''.  It is typically found in late summer to early autumn. In the United States' [[Dietary supplement|supplement]] market, as well as in [[Asian grocery store]]s, the mushroom is known by its Japanese name '''''maitake''''' (舞茸, "dancing mushroom"). Throughout [[Italian American]] communities in the northeastern United States, it is commonly known as the '''signorina''' mushroom.
''G. frondosa'' should not be confused with ''Laetiporus sulphureus'', another edible [[bracket fungus]] that is commonly called [[chicken of the woods]] or "sulphur shelf". Like all polypores, the fungus becomes inedible when older, because it is then too tough to eat.

The fungus is native to China,<ref>{{Cite book|title = Jim Meuninck - Basic Illustrated Edible and Medicinal Mushrooms, pp. 13-14, Rowman & Littlefield, 1 Jun 2015 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ldXRCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA14|accessdate = 27 April 2017|isbn = 9781493014682|last1 = Meuninck|first1 = Jim|date = 2015-06-01}}</ref> the northeastern part of [[Japan]] and North America, and is prized in traditional [[Chinese herbology|Chinese and Japanese herbology]] as a [[medicinal mushroom]]. It is widely eaten in Japan, and its popularity in western cuisine is growing, although the mushroom has been reported to cause [[allergic reaction]]s in rare cases.

==Description==
Like the [[sulphur shelf]] mushroom, ''G. frondosa'' is a [[perennial]] [[fungus]] that often grows in the same place for a number of years in succession. It occurs most prolifically in the northeastern regions of the [[United States]], but has been found as far west as [[Idaho]].

''G. frondosa''  grows from an underground [[tuber]]-like structure known as a [[sclerotium]], about the size of a [[potato]]. The fruiting body, occurring as large as 100 cm, is a cluster consisting of multiple grayish-brown [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]]s which are often curled or spoon-shaped, with wavy margins and 2–7 cm broad. The undersurface of each cap bears about one to three pores per millimeter, with the tubes rarely deeper than 3 mm. The milky-white [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] (stalk) has a branchy structure and becomes tough as the mushroom matures.

In Japan, the ''maitake'' can grow to more than {{convert|100|lb|kg|abbr=on}}, earning this giant mushroom the title "king of mushrooms".  Maitake is one of the major culinary mushrooms used in Japan, the others being ''[[shiitake]], [[shimeji]]'', and ''[[enoki]]''. They are used in a wide variety of dishes, often being a key ingredient in ''[[nabemono]]'' or cooked in foil with butter.

==Medical research and use==
In 2009, a phase I/II human trial, conducted by [[Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Center]], showed ''maitake'' could stimulate the immune systems of breast cancer patients.<ref name="PMD19253021">{{cite journal  |vauthors=Deng G, Lin H, Seidman A, etal |title=A phase I/II trial of a polysaccharide extract from Grifola frondosa (Maitake mushroom) in breast cancer patients: immunological effects |journal=Journal of Cancer Research and Clinical Oncology |volume=135 |issue=9 |pages=1215–21 |date=September 2009 |pmid=19253021 |pmc=3751581 |doi=10.1007/s00432-009-0562-z}}</ref>{{psi|date=December 2017}} Small experiments with human cancer patients have shown it can stimulate immune system cells, such as [[NK cells]].<ref name="pmid14977447">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kodama N, Komuta K, Nanba H |title=Effect of Maitake (Grifola frondosa) D-Fraction on the activation of NK cells in cancer patients |journal=Journal of Medicinal Food |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=371–7 |year=2003 |pmid=14977447 |doi=10.1089/109662003772519949}}</ref>{{psi|date=December 2017}}<ref name="pmid12499658">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kodama N, Komuta K, Sakai N, Nanba H |title=Effects of D-Fraction, a polysaccharide from Grifola frondosa on tumor growth involve activation of NK cells |journal=Biological & Pharmaceutical Bulletin |volume=25 |issue=12 |pages=1647–50 |date=December 2002 |pmid=12499658 |doi=10.1248/bpb.25.1647}}</ref> ''[[In vitro]]'' research has also shown ''G. frondosa'' can stimulate immune system cells.<ref name="pmid15706424">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kodama N, Asakawa A, Inui A, Masuda Y, Nanba H |title=Enhancement of cytotoxicity of NK cells by D-Fraction, a polysaccharide from Grifola frondosa |journal=Oncology Reports |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=497–502 |date=March 2005 |pmid=15706424 |doi=10.3892/or.13.3.497}}</ref>  An ''[[in vivo]]'' experiment showed that it could stimulate both the [[innate immune system]] and [[adaptive immune system]].<ref name="pmid15298759">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kodama N, Murata Y, Nanba H |title=Administration of a polysaccharide from Grifola frondosa stimulates immune function of normal mice |journal=Journal of Medicinal Food |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=141–5 |year=2004 |pmid=15298759 |doi=10.1089/1096620041224012}}</ref>

''In vitro'' research has shown ''maitake'' can induce [[apoptosis]] in various cancer cell lines, and inhibit the growth of various types of cancer cells.<ref name="Ulbricht 2009"/> Small studies with human cancer patients revealed that a portion of this mushroom, known as the ''mitake'' D-fraction, possesses anticancer activity.<ref name="pmid12126464">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kodama N, Komuta K, Nanba H |title=Can maitake MD-fraction aid cancer patients? |journal=Alternative Medicine Review |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=236–9 |date=June 2002 |pmid=12126464 |url=http://www.thorne.com/altmedrev/.fulltext/7/3/236.pdf |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728045324/http://www.thorne.com/altmedrev/.fulltext/7/3/236.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-28 }}</ref>{{ufs|date=December 2017}}<ref name="pmid9616756">{{cite journal |vauthors=Nanba H, Kubo K |title=Effect of Maitake D-fraction on cancer prevention |journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences |volume=833 |issue= 1 Cancer|pages=204–7 |date=December 1997 |pmid=9616756 |doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.1997.tb48611.x|bibcode=1997NYASA.833..204N }}</ref>  ''In vitro'' research demonstrated the mushroom has potential anti[[metastatic]] properties.<ref name="pmid18520039">{{cite journal |vauthors=Masuda Y, Murata Y, Hayashi M, Nanba H |title=Inhibitory effect of MD-Fraction on tumor metastasis: involvement of NK cell activation and suppression of intercellular adhesion molecule (ICAM)-1 expression in lung vascular endothelial cells |journal=Biological & Pharmaceutical Bulletin |volume=31 |issue=6 |pages=1104–8 |date=June 2008 |pmid=18520039 |doi=10.1248/bpb.31.1104}}</ref>

''Maitake'' has a [[hypoglycemic]] effect, and may be beneficial for the management of [[diabetes]].<ref name="Ulbricht 2009">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ulbricht C, Weissner W, Basch E, Giese N, Hammerness P, Rusie-Seamon E, Varghese M, Woods J |title=Maitake mushroom (''Grifola frondosa''): systematic review by the natural standard research collaboration |journal=Journal of the Society for Integrative Oncology |year=2009 |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=66–72 |pmid=19476741}}</ref>  It lowers blood sugar because the mushroom naturally contains an [[alpha glucosidase inhibitor]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Matsuur H, Asakawa C, Kurimoto M, Mizutani J |title=Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor from the seeds of balsam pear (Momordica charantia) and the fruit bodies of Grifola frondosa |journal=Bioscience, Biotechnology, and Biochemistry |volume=66 |issue=7 |pages=1576–8 |date=July 2002 |pmid=12224646 |doi=10.1271/bbb.66.1576}}</ref>

This species contains [[antioxidants]] and may partially inhibit the enzyme [[cyclooxygenase]].<ref name="pmid12475274">{{cite journal |vauthors=Zhang Y, Mills GL, Nair MG |title=Cyclooxygenase inhibitory and antioxidant compounds from the mycelia of the edible mushroom Grifola frondosa |journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry |volume=50 |issue=26 |pages=7581–5 |date=December 2002 |pmid=12475274 |doi=10.1021/jf0257648}}</ref>  An extract of ''maitake'' inhibited [[angiogenesis]] via inhibition of the [[vascular endothelial growth factor]].<ref name="pmid19053855">{{cite journal  |vauthors=Lee JS, Park BC, Ko YJ, etal |title=Grifola frondosa (maitake mushroom) water extract inhibits vascular endothelial growth factor-induced angiogenesis through inhibition of reactive oxygen species and extracellular signal-regulated kinase phosphorylation |journal=Journal of Medicinal Food |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=643–51 |date=December 2008 |pmid=19053855 |doi=10.1089/jmf.2007.0629}}</ref>

[[Lys-N]] is a unique [[protease]] found in ''maitake''.<ref>{{Cite journal| issn = 0021-924X| volume = 124| issue = 1| pages = 157–162| last = Nonaka| first = T|author2=Y Hashimoto |author3=K Takio | title = Kinetic characterization of lysine-specific metalloendopeptidases from Grifola frondosa and Pleurotus ostreatus fruiting bodies| journal = Journal of Biochemistry| date = July 1998 | pmid = 9644258| doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.jbchem.a022074}}<!--| accessdate = 2010-07-01--></ref> Lys-N is used for [[proteomics]] experiments because of its protein cleavage specificity.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1038/nmeth.1204| pmid = 18425140| issn = 1548-7091| volume = 5| issue = 5| pages = 405–407| last = Taouatas| first = Nadia|author2=Madalina M Drugan |author3=Albert J R Heck |author4=Shabaz Mohammed | title = Straightforward ladder sequencing of peptides using a Lys-N metalloendopeptidase| journal = Nat Methods| date = May 2008}}<!--| accessdate = 2010-07-01--></ref>
